tweet: Amazon fined $886.6m (£636m) for allegedly breaking European Union data protection laws

Australia says Facebook will reverse a decision to block access to news content
Google applications including YouTube, Gmail and Docs suffer rare outage, with users unable to access services
Obituary: John le Carré, the pseudonym of author David Cornwell, judged by many to be the master of the spy novel
Russian group which hacked 2016 Democratic campaign are again targeting US election, says Microsoft
Bill Gates stepping down from Microsoft board to spend more time on philanthropic activities
Pope Francis rules against allowing married men to be ordained to address shortage of priests in Amazon region
Google does not have to apply the "right to be forgotten" across world, Europe's top court rules
Simon Cheng, UK consulate worker from Hong Kong detained in mainland China, is released, his Facebook page says
Sir Jonathan Ive to leave Apple after two decades as its chief designer

Facebook bug exposed photos of up to 6.8 million users, including pictures they had not posted
Google says it has sacked 48 people, including 13 senior managers, over sexual harassment claims in past two years
Facebook hires former deputy PM Sir Nick Clegg as head of global affairs and communications
Facebook says the security flaw has been fixed and it has informed police. In a statement it says "we have yet to determine whether these accounts were misused or any information accessed"
50 million Facebook accounts compromised, the social network says - in all, 90m accounts will have to take action
"Nothing criminal" about men named by UK over poisoning of ex-Russian spy Sergei Skripal and daughter, Putin says
Apple has just become the first US company to hit a value of $1 trillion (that's $1,000,000,000,000)

Four boys in total have been brought out of the cave complex, Thai navy confirms in official Facebook post     Live:
Pair found unconscious in Wiltshire poisoned with same nerve agent as ex-Russian spy Sergei Skripal, police say
Visa says cardholders should now be able to use their cards, with systems operating at "close to normal" levels, blaming earlier disruption on "hardware failure"
Visa says some card payments are currently failing across the UK and elsewhere in Europe
Cambridge Analytica, the firm that harvested Facebook data to help Trump in the US election, is to shut down
